title: Synthetic Recap
body:
DETROIT (AP) — In a game defined by grit and a single, spectacular force of will, Grant Hill authored a masterpiece. On a night where points were a precious commodity, Hill was a one-man offensive torrent, pouring in a career-high and utterly dominant 47 points to power the Detroit Pistons to a 92-79 victory over the Washington Wizards.

The final score belies the struggle. This was not a shootout; it was a defensive grind, a classic late-90s battle where every basket was earned. While his teammates combined for just 45 points, Hill was in a different stratosphere. He was relentless, slicing through the Washington defense with an artistry that bordered on cruelty. His 47 points were not just a number; they were a statement, accounting for over half of his team's total output and single-handedly outscoring the entire Wizards' starting lineup.

Washington, led by Chris Webber's 21 points and 12 rebounds, had no answer. They fought valiantly, with Tracy Murray providing a 17-point spark off the bench, but every run was met with a cold, calculated response from Hill. His performance was both surgical and savage, a display of skill and will that left the Palace of Auburn Hills in a state of awe.

In an era often defined by its physicality, Grant Hill provided a breathtaking lesson in graceful dominance. This was not just a win; it was an event. For one night, he wasn't just the best player on the court—he was the only story that mattered, a soloist commanding the orchestra in a symphony of his own design. History will remember the final score, but those who witnessed it will forever remember the night Grant Hill scored 47 and carried a team on his back to victory.
